replies.text: TILT, ElasticSearch is a publically traded company.
You forgot reason 3 they made sure it was a cost savings compared to Elastic Search. Signed, a guy whose shop migrated everything from ES to OS.
I am amazed at how company that doesnt even grow at 20 and lost over 50 mill last Q is trading at 6x its revenue..

I dont think its that simple all. Some enterprise companies or government will not choose open source and sometimes prefer closed source. Sure individual and small projects will use Opensearch, because it is easier to get started, but what larger companies will do is what is important. Because it is a fork of a now closed source application, it is going to diverge more and more and not be a one to one replacement as more time goes on. Just because there is competition doesnt mean anything. I am no expert in evaluating database stock, but I know mongodb is publicly traded and they have a lot of document store database competition and they are still doing fine on the market.

This graph is not proof, its mentions on Reddit. What would be proof is their database falling in usefulness, which I dont think is happening. The problem with open source is the boring work is rarely done, especially if every other cloud provider can pilfer your work. Its the old Redhat vs Debian debate.
between this and hashicorp, I only have so much money for deep otm puts lmao
Just on how much they bring in they are overvalued, I wouldnt be surprised if they even drop in the 50s. The only issue is they get the benefit of the doubt cause they are tech.

I use elasticsearch a lot, the biggest use case for it is using it for systems monitoring and observability, it is however a very bad tool for doing that. It was a great tool about 1015 years ago but its been superseded with much better purpose put tools and they simply cant keep up. As I write this my main project at work is dumping our elasticsearch setup and moving to a competitor.
Thanks for the info

Its not as simple to replace as calling with a different app. I believe their offering will be somewhat sticky when used as an observability product. Their enterprise customers will have it integrated into many different systems and applications, that any migration will be costly not complicated, just involving many components and possibly gaps in being able to monitor live systems. It appears that they have not properly started to squeeze out the juice and with OpenSearch as a backup option they may have to keep somewhat honest. Also, Amazon was free to create their own version based on the licensing terms that Elastic had selected. I would not call that stealing.
Yep was just as surprised as you haha

I should have mentioned that after the backlash, Elasticsearch has gone back to being open source again. So both are open source options but Elasticsearch has to convince people that their solution is not only better than Opensearch, but that its worth adding a vendor like Elastic to manage their service. With the eroded trust, I would bet against experienced engineering managers in the DevOps space trusting Elastic again. The amount of added work Elastic put on engineering teams to analyze pricing with the changing of licenses really confused the market and a lot of teams opted to switch to Opensearch even though their search as of now is not superior. But Amazon looks committed to improving Opensearch and if I were a betting man, Id bet on Amazons ability to improve and close the gap.

Im not sure why you believe it would be limited to individual and small projects, AWS has become the backbone of the server world like reddit. AWS has such a big portion of the cloud marketshare they essentially dictate what gets used, you could even argue it borders into anticompetitive. It kind of reminds me of when Microsoft packaged IE in with the OS to kill the competition. I think OPs reasoning is pretty good, no idea how it will play out though.
Hashicorp is set to be acquired by IBM
Which competitor?
why is IBM making a comeback?
Probably Grafana cloud, but not for sure yet.

IBM isnt really the same company anymore. They spun a lot of their legacy businesses off in Kyndryl, which has been a complete disaster since the spinoff still down like 43, though to be fair it lost most of its value in the first month or so of that spinoff and has slowly worked its way up since.
What problems with elastic are you trying to solve for exactly

Are you asking as an engineer or a business person trying to understand the company? In general, their observability stack is difficult to use, has poor performance, and requires too much baby sitting to keep it working. A big issue is to setup alerts you have to write a 200 line json file in a propritary query language, then combine and massage the results with another scripting language to alert you if you have a database running low on storage. For someone who isnt an expert on writing alerts, it may mean a day or two massaging a query to alert on something trivial that should take a few minutes.
Ive setup 20 alerts so far and it doesnt seem that hard to me. Perhaps Im missing something though?
Watchers or alert rules? Alert rules are new and simple but are limited in what you can do with them.
Alert rules I think. What are watchers?

Alert rules are very limited, if you need to something like divide disk usage by disk capacity you have to use a watcher instead of an alert rule. Alert rules only got added in version 8 of elastcisearch and didnt exist previously. Watchers require you to write the elasticsearch query by hand, the trigger, and the action. Holy shit.. that is a lot to unpack on mobile. We use Datadog for metrics and elastic for logging so luckily I dont have to deal with that. How do you even writedebug something like that
If you are smart you can use kibana to write part of it for you, but its mostly magic, voodoo and google.

I figured you were new, thats okay. Try to learn as much as you can about options before you waste your cash. There is a metric to options, several actually, but one in particular called implied volatility IV for short. Iv plays a factor into options price, and iv is driven by expected events that would drive market price. Earnings is a big one, dates of known contract announcements or company announcements. The market knows all of this and tracks it through IV. The closer you get to these events, the IV will rise, causing the price of an option to rise with it. So by buying options for known events as far away from them as you can stomach, the cheaper you can get that same option for. You have to balance that with how much you think the price will change before that event though. Options are simple yet complicated. So if you buy an option today for earnings tomorrow, it will likely be as expensive as that option gets. Starting the moment the event happens, the iv begins to drop dramatically, lowering the price of the option. This is known as iv crush if you have heard that term used.
